New view on Ventoux: France Big Ride

The opening scene of Keith Floyd’s 1987 series Floyd On France begins with the restaurateur and bon vivant rattling through Les Gorges de la Nesque in an open-topped Citroën. His mission is to educate lumpen Brits on the gastronomic and cultural wonders of Provence, and three decades later it would seem he has succeeded.

Nowadays, I’d be pushed to find a compatriot who wasn’t familiar with the joys of ratatouille, bouillabaisse or aioli. Nor would I be able to find a cyclist who didn’t know the name of Mont Ventoux.

Mont Ventoux’s wild side: France Big Ride

Cyclist magazine issue 143: on sale now!

The Giant of Provence looms larger than any peak in the history of cycling. Sitting in isolation, Ventoux’s famously barren upper reaches, HC status and storied inclusions in the Tour de France make it a superstar among mountains. Add in the doomed romance of Tom Simpson, who died just short of the summit in 1967, and its mythical status is secured.

Eulogised consistently since the poet Petrarch wandered up it during the 14th century, Ventoux is a mountain that has spawned a mountain of writing, plenty of it in this magazine. Cyclist has visited its slopes on numerous occasions, but we are always on the hunt for new and intriguing approaches to old favourites, and in Les Gorges de la Nesque we think we’ve found it.

Whenever the Tour de France tackles Mont Ventoux, it usually favours dragging riders up to its peak from the town of Bédoin at its southern edge. There have, on occasion, been ascents via the communes of Malaucène and Sault as well, but what it has never done is take the path up Les Gorges de la Nesque, meaning it bypasses one of the most picturesque roads in Europe. This strikes me as a mistake.

There is a benefit to this oversight, however. The route’s lack of exposure means that on the morning Cyclist passes through, we have it almost entirely to ourselves. Threading through gaps punched into the valley’s sides or pinned to its vertiginous balconies perched above sheer cliffs, I’d opt for seclusion and scenery over celebrity status any day.

Breakfast in Bédoin

Our day starts traditionally enough with coffee and croissants in Bédoin. From here, we join the throngs heading down the D974 to begin the standard approach to Ventoux, but we won’t be staying with them for long.

Just outside of Bédoin, with our ride barely underway, we make a pilgrimage to one of cycling’s more unusual landmarks. Sitting neglected beside a roundabout is La Butte des Champions du Mont Ventoux.

It’s a hillock that contains the ‘shrubbery of glory’, a collection of cultivated plants tended in honour of the first rider up Ventoux whenever the Tour, Critérium du Dauphiné or Paris-Nice races pass through. Beside it, a board lists each alongside their corresponding shrub. So we find Bernard Thévenet, first over in the 1972 Tour, commemorated by plant number four, a somewhat straggly rhododendron.

More recent riders have been added to the board using permanent marker, although some, including Chris Froome, 2013, are as yet unrepresented among the planting. Maybe they’re still waiting for him to select the appropriate shrub.

After our horticultural diversion, we push on, veering away from the general flow of riders heading along the D974 and instead turning south through vineyards towards the picturesque and sparsely inhabited communes of Flassan and Villes-sur-Auzon. Now well away from the masses, our circuitous route leads upwards through the forest that lies between these last holdouts of civilisation and the entrance to Les Gorges de la Nesque.

Advancing from the close cover of the early slopes, the views open up progressively like a film spooled forward by the action of our pedals. At first, we can only see as far as the next turn, but soon we emerge from the woods to be greeted by far-reaching views over a lush, green valley with a long scar on its left flank showing the path of the road we’re following.

As we continue, the sides of the valley move closer together, their walls becoming steeper and the drop to the side of the road becoming more precipitous. Eventually the walls become so steep that vegetation struggles to cling to it, revealing vast faces of limestone rock. The road twists and weaves, following the contours of the valley as it turns into a gorge carved over millennia by the river Nesque.

We pass through tunnels blasted through the solid rock and skirt along cliff edges, barely daring to peer over the edge and thankful that the road is free of traffic. It’s stunning and quite unlike most people’s idea of a ride to Ventoux. After climbing gently for a number of kilometres, we stop at a vantage point to look out over the top of the gorge. Impressive though the views are, at this point we’re still only 740m above sea level, which means there’s still more than 1,000m of climbing to go.

However, while we’re appreciating the view down the valley our meditations are interrupted by grunts and squeaks from the nearby woods. Typically, no good comes of investigating such things, however my guide for today, Spencer, assures me there is an innocent explanation for what I’m hearing.

A cabin in the woods

Apparently, an American couple moved into a near-abandoned building and founded a sanctuary for the local boars, which, like everything from hikers to songbirds, live in perpetual danger of being blasted by local hunters. Located where most riders stop for a rest, they’ve taken to scavenging scraps from passing cyclists and so gained a kind of celebrity status.

I consider rummaging in my pocket for a suitable snack to offer, but at that moment someone unseen throws something from the building. Given the uproar of squealing, I assume it’s the boars’ actual lunch, and the horror movie vibes emanating from the scene suggest I’d be wise to leave them be.

Pigs behind us, the descent and gradual climb through an arable landscape to the town of Sault would be one of the nicest sections of most UK rides. However, because this is Provence it’s barely worth a mention.

Spencer tells me that, had we arrived a week earlier, the region would have been bedecked with meadows of sweet-smelling lavender. Unfortunately local farmers have been through and scythed it all up, denying an Instagramable if hackneyed shot of us riding through a sea of purple-striped fields.

Never mind – even the stubbly meadows are beautiful. The medieval commune of Sault itself is also charming. Annoyingly so, as our schedule allows no time for ravitaillement at one of its excellent cafes. Being in Provence and adopting Floyd as my spirit guide, I’d rather imagined this a prerequisite, but sadly it’s not to be if we are to make it across Ventoux in daylight.

When we leave Sault, we join the eastern approach to the mountain, and even with 40km of riding under our belts, we’re still less than halfway up in terms of vertical ascent, and like the long Provençal lunch I’d envisioned us now enjoying, Ventoux can’t be rushed.

Regardless of which route you take up, its profile looks similar. In fact, irrespective of the angle Ventoux is viewed from, its shape on Strava looks precisely like its geographical profile in real life. Disconnected from any other peaks, it is a vast, lonely mountain, and although its sides are gradual, they all rise to a pinnacle that’s 1,910m high.

After 25km of climbing from Sault, we home in on the bits I recognise from the telly. These take us first through more fields and then onto slopes too high and wild to farm. Soon the gradient settles itself at around 6%, just as we also settle in for the grind.

Despite Ventoux’s undoubted popularity, our bit of tarmac is remarkably quiet. Perhaps this is because the route via Sault is the easiest of the three main ways to the summit. However, if the route from Bédoin is the steepest and best known, heading up from Malaucène in the west seems to me to be going in the wrong direction.

It means climbing the mountain’s north face, which means missing out on slogging up the iconic barren southern slope with its white moonscapes. Given that going via Sault means you can ride Les Gorges de la Nesque before tackling the same final 6km from Chalet Reynard as the Bédoin route, I’ve no idea why the Tour hasn’t yet jumped on it.

Sunset on Ventoux

This is the tough bit. As we grind our way upwards on the road from Sault, the tree cover goes from full to sparse, mirroring the levels of energy in my legs. Despite being visible for hundreds of kilometres around, at this point of the climb the summit is hidden, giving us less of a way to gauge our progress. It feels like a long drag to get to Chalet Reynard.

Sitting at 1,417 metres, it’s more of a cafe than a chalet, but its status in cycling folklore is assured by being the point at which the wooded lower slopes of Ventoux give way to the bare, white upper reaches. It’s also the finishing line for early-season races or where competitors find themselves curtailed when the not-uncommon 100kmh mistral winds scour the summit. The gradient picks up from here, although luckily today the weather is dead calm.

A Provençal haze begins to settle over the scene below us, while the setting sun works to change the colour of the limestone scree slopes above. We’ve left it late in the day to make our assault on the summit, and as we race towards the top we’re treated to a spectacular light show. With the sun in front, the last few ramps seem like they might propel us off the mountain and straight into the sky. Above us, bathed in red and purple light, is the weather station and perhaps the most famous view in cycling.

More than anywhere I’ve ridden, Ventoux has the effect of making you feel like you’re in your own cycling drama. And there have been a few. For me, it’s impossible to beat Armstrong and Pantani fighting it out in 2000, which I must have first watched while still at school. Thévenet beating Merckx in 1972 might be the connoisseur’s choice, with Chris Froome running up the mountain following a crash in 2016 also worthy of a mention.

Even the most jaded cyclist can’t help but get swept up in imagining themselves as somehow part of its cycling history. Then, just before the top, comes the Tom Simpson memorial. Forever only a kilometre away from the summit, it marks the point where the British rider collapsed at the 1967 Tour de France during a doomed attempt to push through illness with the aid of amphetamines and brandy.

With the weather tower marking the finishing line, we swing around the final bend just as the sun hits the horizon. The view from the top is amazing, but we’ve little time to enjoy it. Tired and with dwindling daylight and vitality, we do something Floyd would have been horrified by: we call up the pizza place in Malaucène. And, with our order in, we race both the chefs and the fading light as we plummet over 1,500m down the rapidly darkening mountain.

A pinch of Sault

The day the Tour came to town

There are three roads up Mont Ventoux: from Bédoin in the south; from Malaucène in the west; from Sault in the east. And despite the Tour de France’s love affair with the Giant of Provence, the race has only ever taken the Sault road (the approach of this Big Ride) once. That was in 2021, when Stage 11 saw two ascents of Ventoux to give the riders twice the pain and fans twice the fun.

The Sault approach came first, with French favourite Julian Alaphilippe (Deceuninck-QuickStep) leading the breakaway over the top. After descending to Malaucène, the race doubled back to tackle the mountain again, this time from the usual Bédoin approach.

Trek-Segafredo’s Kenny Elissonde made an early attack, but he was eventually reeled in and passed by Belgian superhero Wout van Aert (Jumbo-Visma), who crossed the summit first and held his lead on a breakneck descent to take the stage win.

The rider’s ride

Vitus Venon Evo, from £2,999, vitusbikes.com

Did you know that there’s a gravel route up Ventoux? I do, because I’ve done it – on this bike (see issue 122). The Vitus Venon Evo is a bike that can be a rough-and-tumble gravel grinder one day, and a slick and quick road machine the next.

It has space for tyres up to 40mm when heading off-road, but with its refined silhouette and fully integrated cockpit, it looks every bit the road racer with a set of deep-section rims slotted in. Even the mudguard mounts are subtle enough to go unnoticed. However you set it up, the Venon Evo is light, assured, fairly comfy and fun to ride.

How we did it

Travel

Marseille is the nearest airport to Ventoux, and the drive from there to our starting point is around 110km. It’s possible to get from Marseille to Bédoin by public transport, although the nearest train station is Carpentras, about 15km away, which means either riding the last bit (all uphill) or somehow squeezing your bike onto a bus.

Accommodation

Cyclist stayed at the splendid La Ferme des Bélugues, situated just a few kilometres from Malaucène at the foot of Ventoux. It’s a beautiful, rustic gîte, run by Karen and Spencer Martin, the latter of whom was our guide for the day. There’s a full bike workshop, plus a pool and exceedingly comfy rooms to relax after a hard day on the hill. A true gem – find out more at lafermedesbelugues.com.

Thanks

Many thanks to Karen and Spencer at La Ferme des Bélugues, who went above and beyond to accommodate us at the end of a busy season. Experts on the surrounding region, they’re excellent company and supremely skilled at suggesting everything from routes to restaurants.
